Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Links Between Magma Source Characteristics, Shallow Plumbing, and Eruptive Styles in Mafic Intraplate Volcanic Fields (Lunar Crater Volcanic Field, Nevada)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. Volcanoes that form in intraplate fields, although small and (mainly) monogenetic, result from eruptive phenomena ranging from quiet effusion of lava to relatively explosive Strombolian activity and, if external water interacts with ascending magma, hydrovolcanic activity. The generation and eruption of magmas in relatively small batches over dispersed areas, often with evidence for direct ascent from the upper mantle to the surface, suggests a driving process that is hybrid between strong hotspot-style mantle upwelling and scattered pockets of incipient melt that are passively mobilized by tectonic deformation (high- and low-magma flux end members of volcanic fields, respectively).

Integrated approaches involving physical volcanology, petrology, and geochemistry can provide important insights into these processes and the links between magma dynamics at depth and eruption processes on the surface. The lack of long-lived crustal magma reservoirs) allows investigation of the influences of deep magma source(s) and shallow plumbing systems on eruption styles. It is hypothesized that eruption style is influenced by physical and chemical characteristics of magma sources. To test this hypothesis comprehensive data will be integrated from the well-exposed Lunar Crater Volcanic Field (central Nevada). Direct studies of eruptive facies, of exposed shallow conduits (at older, eroded volcanoes), and of abundant mantle xenoliths will provide insights into the magma sources and ascent processes. Existing data on broad geochemicsl trends and age relationships will be integrated with new EarthScope seismic tomography data to provide a framework for understanding: (1) the interplay between pre-existing structure, topography, and vent location; (2) shallow plumbing geometries; (3) shallow controls on magmatic eruption styles, including relationships between eruption style, clast texture and shape, volatile content, and mineral chemistry; (4) spatial and temporal variations in magma sources and magma differentiation processes at individual volcanoes and across the field as a whole; (5) depth of melting and volatile contents of parent magmas; and (6) correspondence between volcano location, melting depths, and upper mantle seismic structure.


Broader impacts. This work will support improvements in volcanic risk assessment, both in terms of the probability (volcano timing and location) of future events and in terms of their consequences (related to eruption processes). The project will also support the training of three Ph.D. students (two of whom are female minorities) and will have a component of international collaboration with the volcanology and geochemistry group at the Universidad Autónoma de México. The proposing team is in communication both with the Shoshone Tribe (Duckwater Reservation) and the Bureau of Land Management so that we can share our results with them and (through BLM) with the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Lunar Crater Volcanic Field in central Nevada is an area of recent volcanism in the SW United States. This volcanic field occupies an area of approximately one thousand square kilometers, and comprises more than one hundred volcanic vents. Each vent is thought to erupt only once, thus this volcanic field is referred to as a “monogenetic” volcanic field. Although monogenetic volcanism typically results in relatively small volcanic centers that are less explosive than volcanoes such as those in the Cascades, it nevertheless can pose significant hazards. Historic monogenetic eruptions in North America, such as Parícutin and Jorullo volcanoes in Mexico, document their potential for destruction of buildings, farmland, transportation routes, and livelihoods. The potential for disruption to air traffic poses another significant hazard, should such an eruption occur today.

This project was part of a multi-institution collaborative effort to gain a better understanding of the age distributions, compositions, and eruptive styles of the volcanic centers in the Lunar Crater Volcanic Field, all of which have important implications for understanding the volcanic hazards in the region. Our results have demonstrated that, contrary to previous notions, multiple eruptions can occur in a single location. This is important because it suggests that a given location is not immune to future eruptions despite the pre-existence of a monogenetic volcanic center. Our results also demonstrate that the volcanic vents in the Lunar Crater Volcanic Field occur in clusters of vents that can range in age significantly, spanning nearly one million years. The longevity of these clusters, together with a new age determination for one eruption of only thirty-five thousand years, suggests that future volcanism could be expected in this region.

The studies of the rock compositions have led to a better understanding of the cause of volcanism in this region. Unlike highly active volcanic regions such as the Cascades, where ongoing tectonic processes (subduction, or return of oceanic crust into the deep mantle of the Earth) easily explains the volcanism, the cause of volcanism in the Lunar Crater Volcanic Field has been less well understood. It is part of the Basin and Range, where active faulting occurs, but our results show that the cause of volcanism may be related to ancient processes similar to those occurring today in the Cascades, but which in this case occurred tens of millions to almost a billion years in the past. These results are important, because they suggest persistence over long geologic timescales of conditions that lead to mantle melting and pursuant volcanism in geographic regions that otherwise would not be expected to be volcanically active.

This project has also contributed to training and professional development of students. Students have been trained in fundamental methods of scientific investigation, critical thinking, state-of-the-art analytical techniques, and writing, all fundamental skills for an educated and effective workforce of the future.

The results of this project have been provided to the community via presentation in a meeting on Volcanism of the American Southwest in Flagstaff, Arizona. In addition to scientists, the meeting involved a diverse group including local and regional emergency responders, land use planners, as well USGS employees who coordinate national response to natural hazards including volcanic hazards. The meeting resulted in the publication of U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2013-1026, as well as a publically available web site with the related presentations.
